source.3735ae8b:
def col_num(df,column_name):#to count  survey results.
    k=cc(df,column_name + ".+")
    data=[]
    count=[]
    per=[]
    for i in range(1,k):
        data_count=(df[column_name + "Part_"+ "{}".format(i)].value_counts())
        data.append(data_count.index[0])
        count.append(data_count.values[0])
    other=df[column_name+"OTHER"].value_counts()
    data.append(other.index[0])
    count.append(other.values[0])
    for i in count:
        k=(np.round_((i/sum(count))*100,2))
        per.append(k)
    return data,count,per
source.43bb3282:
data,count,percentage=col_num(mlprofessionals,"Q26_A_")
d={}
for x,y in zip(data,percentage):
    d[x]=y
    
colors=[]
for i in data:
    if re.search("Amazon", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("AWS", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("Azure", i):
        colors.append("#007fff")
    elif re.search("Google", i):
        colors.append("#0F9D58")
    else:
        colors.append("lightgrey")
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

fig = plt.figure(figsize = (14, 8))
ax = fig.add_subplot()

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ax.bar(d.keys(), d.values(), color=colors,edgecolor = "black")


for i, (k, v) in enumerate(d.items()):
    ax.text(k, 
            v +0.8,
            v, 
            color ="black", 
            fontsize = 12, 
            horizontalalignment = 'center', 
            verticalalignment = 'center'
           )

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ax.tick_params(axis = 'x', labelrotation = 90, labelsize = 12)
ax.tick_params(axis = 'y', labelsize = 12)


ax.set_ylim(0, 35)


ax.set_xlabel("Cloud computing platforms",fontsize=16)
ax.set_ylabel("Percentage of respondents",fontsize=16)

ax.set_title("Cloud Computing Platforms that ML professionals use on regular basis", fontsize = 18)

source.0a16f444:
data,count,percentage=col_num(mlprofessionals,"Q27_A_")

colors=[]
for i in data:
    if re.search("Amazon", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("AWS", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("Azure", i):
        colors.append("#007fff")
    elif re.search("Google", i):
        colors.append("#0F9D58")
    else:
        colors.append("lightgrey")
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (14, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot()
i=0
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
for x, y in zip(percentage, data):
    ax.hlines(y = y, 
               xmin = 0,  
               xmax = x, 
               linewidth = 2,
               alpha = 1,
               color = colors[i] )
    ax.scatter(x, 
                y, 
                color = colors[i], 
                s = 300,edgecolor = "black",
                alpha = 1)
    i=i+1
    ax.text(x+.4, 
         y, 
         round(x, 2), 
         color = "black",
         horizontalalignment='left', 
         verticalalignment='center',
         multialignment="left",
         size = 12)

# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ax.set_title("Cloud Computing products that ML professionals use on regular basis",fontsize=20)

ax.set_xlim(0, 25)


ax.set_xlabel("Percentage of respondents",fontsize=16)
ax.set_ylabel("Cloud computing products",fontsize=16)


ax.xaxis.set_tick_params(labelsize=12)
ax.yaxis.set_tick_params(labelsize=12)

ax.spines["top"].set_color("None")
ax.spines["left"].set_color("None")

ax.spines['right'].set_position(('data',0))
ax.spines['right'].set_color('black')

source.476db7cd:
data,count,percentage=col_num(mlprofessionals,"Q28_A_")
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (14, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot()

colors=[]
for i in data:
    if re.search("Amazon", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("Azure", i):
        colors.append("#007fff")
    elif re.search("Google", i):
        colors.append("#0F9D58")
    else:
        colors.append("lightgrey")
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

i=0
for x_, y_ in zip(data, percentage):
    ax.scatter(y_, x_, color = colors[i],edgecolor = "black", alpha = 1, s = 300)
    i=i+1
    
    ax.text(y_+.6,x_,
         round(y_, 2), 
         color = "black",
         horizontalalignment='left', 
         verticalalignment='center',
         fontweight="medium",
         size = 12)
    
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ax.set_xlim(0, 45)


ax.set_xlabel("Percentage of respondents", fontsize=16)
ax.set_ylabel("Specific Machine Learning products",fontsize=16)

ax.xaxis.set_tick_params(labelsize=12)
ax.yaxis.set_tick_params(labelsize=12)

ax.set_title("Specific Machine Learning products that ML professionals use on regular basis", fontsize = 18)


ax.grid(which = 'major', axis = 'y', linestyle = '--');

source.86491d61:
data,count,percentage=col_num(mlprofessionals,"Q29_A_")

colors=[]
for i in data:
    if re.search("Amazon", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("AWS", i):
        colors.append("#FF9900")
    elif re.search("Azure", i):
        colors.append("#007fff")
    elif re.search("Microsoft", i):
        colors.append("#007fff")
    elif re.search("Google", i):
        colors.append("#0F9D58")
    elif re.search("SQL", i):
        colors.append("indigo")
        
    elif re.search("MongoDB", i):
        colors.append("magenta")
    else:
        colors.append("lightgrey")
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

fig = plt.figure(figsize = (14, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot()
i=0
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

for x_, y_ in zip(data, percentage):
    
    ax.scatter(x_, y_, color = colors[i],s=400)
    
   
    ax.vlines(x_, ymin = 0, ymax = y_, color = colors[i], alpha = 1,linewidth = 2)
    
   
    ax.text(x_, y_ + 0.6, round(y_, 1), horizontalalignment='center',fontsize=12)
    i=i+1
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ax.set_ylim(0, 20)

ax.tick_params(axis = 'x', labelrotation = 90, labelsize = 12)
ax.tick_params(axis = 'y', labelsize = 12)


ax.set_ylabel("Percentage of respondents",fontsize=16)
ax.set_xlabel("Big data products",fontsize=16)


ax.set_title("Big data products that ML professionals use on regular baiss",fontsize=18)

source.6dd8753f:
#### There are various existing tools in the Data Science field that are making our tasks more acheivable. Newer tools are coming into the data science fields which are making life's of data science comfortable by integrating data visualization, ML models,deep learning and computation power.  These tools are critical for anyone looking to develop expertise  in the domain of Data Science.  We all know that  picking the right tools can make a world of difference.

#### One such right tool is data analytics in cloud computing. At this time, organizations are investing maximum resources to shift Big Data into cloud and analyzing this big data in cloud. By this organizations are  gaining benefits of tackling large sets of data for decision making and reducing the overall cost of infrastructure. It is essential for data scientist to develop knowledge of data analysis in cloud computing products. We know that there are three major players in cloud market.  As of October 2020, Canalys reports that **AWS has 32% of the market, Azure is at 19% of the market, Google Cloud at 7%, Alibaba Cloud close behind at 6%, and other clouds with 37%**. 

#### From the market share statistics, it is clear that developing data science skills on AWS platfrom will have greater advantage over others. However, This may not be a thoughtful decision as we are just considering the market share. Let us look into the responses of experienced ML professional respondents on cloud computing related questions. 

#### From this analysis, we will generate a concerate decision on trending cloud computing products.
source.a3a18326: ### Consideration: Respondents with generater than 2 years of experience on machine learning methods as experienced ML professionals.
